channel.title: Nature Communications - current - nature.com science feeds
channel.description: Nature Communications is an online-only, multidisciplinary journal dedicated to publishing high-quality research in all areas of the biological, physical and chemical sciences. Papers published by the journal represent important advances of significance to specialists within each field.

item.title: Thermochromic aggregation-induced dual phosphorescence via temperature-dependent sp3-linked donor-acceptor electronic coupling
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 01 March 2021; doi:10.1038/s41467-021-21676-5

Aggregation-induced emission (AIE) has proven to be a viable strategy to achieve highly efficient room temperature phosphorescence (RTP) in bulk by restricting molecular motions. Here, the authors present an RTP design strategy by combining the concept of AIE and donor-acceptor motif and demonstrate unusual thermochromic dual phosphorescence.
item.dc:title: Thermochromic aggregation-induced dual phosphorescence via temperature-dependent sp3-linked donor-acceptor electronic coupling
item.dc:creator: Tao Wang
Zhubin Hu
Xiancheng Nie
Linkun Huang
Miao Hui
Xiang Sun
Guoqing Zhang

item.title: Immunomodulating nano-adaptors potentiate antibody-based cancer immunotherapy
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 01 March 2021; doi:10.1038/s41467-021-21497-6

Current strategies to boost anti-tumor immune response include the use of immune checkpoint inhibitors and bispecific T cell-engaging antibodies. Here the authors describe a versatile antibody immobilization nanoplatform that can be used to deliver different combinations of immunotherapeutics, showing therapeutic superiority in pre-clinical models.
item.dc:title: Immunomodulating nano-adaptors potentiate antibody-based cancer immunotherapy
item.dc:creator: Cheng-Tao Jiang

item.title: Identification of leukemic and pre-leukemic stem cells by clonal tracking from single-cell transcriptomics
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 01 March 2021; doi:10.1038/s41467-021-21650-1

Leukaemic stem cells drive acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) progression and relapse but they are incompletely characterized. Here, the authors combine single-cell transcriptomics and clonal tracking using nuclear and mitochondrial somatic variants to distinguish healthy, pre-leukaemic and leukaemic stem cells in AML.
item.dc:title: Identification of leukemic and pre-leukemic stem cells by clonal tracking from single-cell transcriptomics

item.title: Differential regulation of β-catenin-mediated transcription via N- and C-terminal co-factors governs identity of murine intestinal epithelial stem cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 01 March 2021; doi:10.1038/s41467-021-21591-9

How downstream regulators of Wnt/β-catenin signalling control the fate of intestinal epithelial stem cells (IESCs) is unclear. Here, the authors show that the transcriptional co-factors interacting with the N- and C-terminal domains of β-catenin differentially regulate Wnt target gene activation, in turn differentially affecting the murine IESC proliferation and differentiation.
item.dc:title: Differential regulation of β-catenin-mediated transcription via N- and C-terminal co-factors governs identity of murine intestinal epithelial stem cells
item.dc:creator: Costanza Borrelli

item.title: S-Trimer, a COVID-19 subunit vaccine candidate, induces protective immunity in nonhuman primates
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 01 March 2021; doi:10.1038/s41467-021-21634-1

Vaccines for SARS-CoV-2 are needed to fight the pandemic. Here the authors show immunogenicity of an adjuvanted subunit vaccine, SARS-CoV-2 spike protein trimerized with trimer-tag technology, in small animal models and protection from SARS-CoV-2 challenge in non-human primates.
item.dc:title: S-Trimer, a COVID-19 subunit vaccine candidate, induces protective immunity in nonhuman primates

item.title: DNA stability: a central design consideration for DNA data storage systems
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 01 March 2021; doi:10.1038/s41467-021-21587-5

DNA has the potential to store vast amounts of data but it is subject to physical decay. In this Perspective, the authors propose that the stability of DNA should be a key consideration in how it is used for data storage.
item.dc:title: DNA stability: a central design consideration for DNA data storage systems
item.dc:creator: Karishma Matange
James M. Tuck
Albert J. Keung

item.title: Photocatalysis-mediated drug-free sustainable cancer therapy using nanocatalyst
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 01 March 2021; doi:10.1038/s41467-021-21618-1

Nanoparticles have been used to reduce the toxicity associated with chemotherapeutic agents. Here, the authors report a Z-scheme SnS1.68-WO2.41 nanocatalyst for photocatalytic generation of oxidative holes and hydrogen molecules for drug-free therapeutic strategy.
item.dc:title: Photocatalysis-mediated drug-free sustainable cancer therapy using nanocatalyst
item.dc:creator: Bin Zhao
Yingshuai Wang
Xianxian Yao
Danyang Chen
Mingjian Fan
Zhaokui Jin
Qianjun He

item.title: Observation of magnetic adatom-induced Majorana vortex and its hybridization with field-induced Majorana vortex in an iron-based superconductor
item.content:encoded:
Nature Communications, Published online: 01 March 2021; doi:10.1038/s41467-021-21646-x

Braiding Majorana modes is essential for topological quantum computing, but it remains difficult to find a suitable platform. Here, the authors report the evidence of hybridization between field-induced and magnetic adatom induced Majorana modes in an iron-based superconductor FeTe0.55Se0.45, providing a possible single-material platform for braiding Majorana modes.
item.dc:title: Observation of magnetic adatom-induced Majorana vortex and its hybridization with field-induced Majorana vortex in an iron-based superconductor
